column12:
Overview

Originally developed for the seven day roguelike challenge, Hoplite follows many genre and setting conventions laid down in Rogue and its successors. It was rebuilt by Magma Fortress for Android and iOS with new art, sound, abilities and achievements. With a goal to retrieve the Fleece of Yendor from the 16th floor, players descend a dungeon filled with demons and wizards. Every death restarts the player at the beginning of the game, and every floor is randomized. Most floors have Altars where players can pray to Apollo, Hermes, Athena and other gods to either regain health or gain ability upgrades, like throwing the spear further or regaining energy with each kill.

Gameplay

Both the player and the enemies can only move once per turn, and moving is the main form of attacking for most units. The basic form of attack, the stab, is done by moving adjacent to an enemy.

Having a spear allows the player to lunge by moving directly towards the enemy (being adjacent doesn't count). Alternatively, players can throw the spear by selecting the item in the bottom right hand corner and choosing a target. Players will need to retrieve it unless they have a special ability.

Leaping costs 50 energy (players gain 10 for moving adjacent an enemy) and it can be combined with other abilities.

Players also have a shield, which can be used to bash enemies or bombs one space away in the direction that the player character is facing.

Players can pray at altars to upgrade their abilities, however, this will remove access to a score bonus. More upgrades can be unlocked by completing Achievements.

Once the Fleece of Yendor is retrieved from Depth 16, players can either return to the surface via a portal to end the game, or continue descending to increase their score. When wearing the fleece you regenerate 1 health whenever you descend a floor.

Abilities & Upgrades

Players can pray at the Altars they find. Praying allows them to refill Health or select one of the following options. Note that players can pray during combat, but it does cost one turn. Many abilities require Sacrifice, which reduces the maximum health by 1, 2 or 3.

Keep in mind: there are no altars beyond Depth 15. Should descend beyond where the fleece is kept, you do so with no more prayers.

Health

Players begin with 3 health and take 1 damage from any enemy attack. Many Ability Upgrades require health to be sacrificed in order to equip them.

Divine Restoration

  • Heals the player completely

Fortitude

  • Increases maximum health by 1

Protection

  • Become temporarily invulnerable after taking damage
  • Sacrifice required: 2 Health
  • Achievement required: Flawless

Move and Stab

Any time the player moves adjacent to an enemy that is already nearby, they will get stabbed. Stabbing does not work when moving directly towards an enemy - that requires a Spear.

Spear

Lunge by moving directly towards, rather than adjacent to, an enemy. By default, players can throw the spear 2 tiles. Of course, players cannot lunge after throwing the spear until the spear is retrieved.

Deep Lunge

  • Lunge penetrates through target, hitting up to two enemies

Follow

  • Teleport to the spear
  • Sacrifice required: 1 Health
  • Achievement required: Rampage

Greater Throw

  • Increases throw distance by 1
  • Sacrifice required: 1 Health

Greater Throw II

  • Increases throw distance by 1
  • Sacrifice required: 1 Health

Superior Throw

  • Further increases throw distance
  • Sacrifice required: 2 Health
  • Achievement required: Dory Master

Plant Spear

  • Throwing the spear into the ground stuns adjacent demons
  • Sacrifice required: 1 Health
  • Achievement required: Victory

Recall

  • Returns the spear
  • Sacrifice required: 1 Health
  • Achievement required: Hermes

Shield

By default, there is a 3 turn cooldown on bash attacks; players can bash any adjacent target back 1 space in the same direction that the player character is facing. Bashing enemies together or against walls can kill them.

Mighty Bash

  • Increases knock back distance by 1

Herculean Bash

  • Further increases knock back distance by 1
  • Achievement required: Aspis Master

Quick Bash

  • Reduces cooldown by 1 Turn

Rapid Bash

  • Further reduces cooldown by 1 Turn
  • Sacrifice required: 1 Health
  • Achievement required: Conflagration

Shielding Bash

  • Blocks all damage for one turn
  • Sacrifice required: 1 Health
  • Achievement required: Optimal Restoration

Spinning Bash

  • Affects all adjacent targets
  • Sacrifice required: 1 Health

Sweeping Bash

  • Affects targets in a 3 tile arc

Greater Sweeping Bash

  • Affects targets in a cone
  • Sacrifice required: 2 Health
  • Achievement required: Atheist

Reaction

  • Bashing propels the player backward
  • Achievement required: Combo Bash

Leaping

By default, Leaping costs 40 energy and has a range of 2 tiles.

Winged Sandals

  • Increase leap distance by 2
  • Sacrifice required: 2 Health

Staggering Leap

  • Stuns adjacent enemies on landing
  • Sacrifice required: 2 Health

Leap Strike

  • Allows leaping onto demons, crushing them
  • Sacrifice required: 2 Health
  • Achievement required: The Depths

Swift Leap

  • Gain an additional free action after leaping
  • Sacrifice required: 2 Health
  • Achievement required: Speed Run

Energy

By default, players begin with 100 energy and receive 10 upon moving adjacent an enemy. Energy is always refilled at the beginning of each floor.

Bloodlust

  • Each kill gains 5 energy
  • Sacrifice require: 1 Health

Greater Bloodlust

  • Killing restores an additional 5 energy
  • Sacrifice required: 1 Health
  • Achievement required: Crush Saga

Greater Energy

  • Increases maximum energy by 20 points

Greater Energy II

  • Increases maximum energy
  • Sacrifice required: 1 Health

Superior Energy

  • Further increases maximum energy
  • Sacrifice required: 3 Health
  • Achievement required: Xiphos Master

Killing Sprees

Agility

  • Killing in three consecutive actions grants an additional free action
  • Sacrifice required: 1 Health
  • Achievement required: Multi Kill

Regeneration

  • Once per depth, killing in three consecutive actions regenerates 1 health
  • Sacrifice required: 1 Health

Surge

  • Killing in three consecutive actions restores all energy, resets cooldowns and returns the spear
  • Sacrifice required: 1 Health

Other

Patience

  • Allows skipping turns

Wizard Beam

  • Throw is replaced by a wizard beam
  • Sacrifice required: 2 Health
  • Achievement required: Demon Partisan

Enemies

Demon Footman: A resident of the underworld that is skilled in melee combat. It can attack adjacent tiles.

Demon Archer: A resident of the underworld that is skilled in ranged combat. It has a maximum range of 5 tiles and cannot attack adjacent tiles. It can only shoot in 6 directions. Will not shoot through allies or altars.

Demon Demolitionist: A resident of the underworld that is able to throw bombs. It has a range of 3 tiles. It can only throw a bomb every 3 turns. Bomb does damage to all tiles adjacent.

Demon Wizard: A resident of the underworld that is able to conjure beams of fire. It has a range of 5 tiles and will hit all tiles in range. It will avoid hitting other demons and cannot fire two turns in a row. Unlike the Archer, can attack all adjacent tiles. Can only shoot in 6 directions. Cannot shoot through Altars.

Achievements

Achievements unlock abilities which can be found at the Altars.

Optimal Restoration

  • Pray for restoration with one heart and zero energy remaining
  • Unlocks: Shielding Bash

Combo Bash

  • Knock a demon into the magma by bashing another demon or bomb into it
  • Unlocks: Reaction

Multi Kill

  • Lunge a demon while stabbing two others in a single move
  • Unlocks: Agility

Rampage

  • Kill at least one demon per turn for seven consecutive turns
  • Unlocks: Follow

Xiphos Master

  • Stab 10 demon footmen by leaping over them
  • Unlocks: Superior Energy

Dory Master

  • Lunge 10 demon archers by leaping directly towards them
  • Unlocks: Superior Throw

Aspis Master

  • Explode 10 demon demolitionists by bashing bombs toward them
  • Unlocks: Herculean Bash

Crush Saga

  • Crush 10 demons by bashing them into solid surfaces
  • Unlocks: Greater Bloodlust

Hermes

  • Reach depth 10
  • Unlocks: Recall

Victory

  • Return the Fleece
  • Unlocks: Plant Spear

The Depths

  • Take the Fleece to depth 27 before returning
  • Unlocks: Leap Strike

Flawless

  • Return the Fleece without taking damage
  • Unlocks: Protection

Speed Run

  • Return the Fleece in under 150 turns
  • Unlocks: Swift Leap

Atheist

  • Return the Fleece without praying
  • Unlocks: Greater Sweeping Bash

Demon Partisan

  • Return the Fleece without Killing any wizards or demolitionists
  • Unlocks: Wizard Beam

Streaker

  • Return the Fleece three games in a row
  • Unlocks: Sword Lunge

Pacifist

  • After picking up the Fleece, reach depth 19 without killing another demon
  • Unlocks: Slashing Lunge

column12:
Overview

Gurumin: A Monstrous Adventure is an action-adventure game developed by Nihon Falcom for PC on December 24, 2004 and was later released for the PlayStation Portable in 2006. Mastiff eventually published Gurumin in the United States on the PSP in 2007 as well as the PC in 2015 and finally the Nintendo 3DS in 2016 with a new port created by Mastiff.

Story

A girl named Parin is sent to live with her grandfather Hyperbolic when her parents set out on an excavation. Parin stumbles across another child in Tiese Town after being told there were no other children in town. This child is being attacked by a dog and is then saved by Parin.

After saving the other little girl, Parin finds out that this girl is not a human, but a monster. Only kids can see these monsters and villagers in Tiese Town think she is talking to herself.

After saving the monster named Pino, Parin is then introduced to her brother Puku. Puku decides to let Parin visit their home of the Monster Village. Monster Village is attacked by phantoms while Parin is in the Potato Ruins and she must help the inhabitants rebuild.

Trivia

  • Gurumin was the first fully 3D game to be developed by Nihon Falcom and its graphics engine would live on at the company for a very long time. During a 2020 interview with Gamer, Toshihiro Kondo revealed that the company's current 3D engine originated from Gurumin which they had been updating and modifying for years. While not all of the company's games used this technology, with some titles instead using Sony's PhyreEngine, Falcom had basically been creating games with a version of Gurumin's engine for over 15 years before finally creating a new engine, which debuted with Kuro no Kiseki in 2021.

Overview

Power Spikes II (known in some Japanese advertisements as Super Volley '94) is a 2D side-scrolling volleyball game developed and released (in conjunction with Taito) by Video System for arcades (running Neo Geo MVS hardware) on October 19, 1994.

The final installment of Video System's volleyball series, Power Spikes II brings numerous additions from the SNES-exclusive Hyper V-Ball to the arcades (including a women's league and a league for super-powered cyborgs).

It is one of the few games made for Neo Geo hardware to receive a Neo Geo CD port (released exclusively in Japan by Video System on March 18, 1995) instead of a home Neo Geo AES release.

column12: The game involves the protagonist, known as Ozzy, being forced to land on a planet after his spaceship runs out of fuel. The aim of the game is to search the levels for diamonds to use as fuel and return them to Ozzy's ship. Ozzy is equipped with a boomerang which he can use to defeat aliens he may encounter along his search and he can explore underground areas with a limited air supply, which instantly refills when he reaches the surface again. Ozzy will die if he hits an enemy or hazard, falls from a great height or runs out of air while underground and once he runs out of lives the game is over.

Overview

100 Hidden Eternals is a hidden objects/puzzle game developed and published by Anatoliy Loginovskikh for PC.

System Requirements

PC

PC MinimumPC Recommended
  • Operating System: Windows 7, 8, 10
  • Processor: 2.3 GHz Dual Core
  • Memory: 1024 MB RAM
  • Graphics: Intel HD 4000
  • Storage: 20 MB available space
  • Sound Card: Any
  • Additional Notes: 1080p, 16:9 recommended. Mouse.

column2: You Pilot A Piece Of S****: GAIDEN

column12: When escaping from a dying planet Sayri is separated from their family. After crash landing Sayri must navigate an unknown world with help from their new quirky friends Stompy and Spiney.

Dangerous Driving is an arcade racing game in the same vein as the Burnout series. The game consists of a handful of different environments broken up into circuits and point to point races and numerous types of cars to drive during events. Game types include standard races, road rage, time attack, and pursuit. Game mechanics are essentially identical to the Burnout games; players build boost by drifting, driving in oncoming traffic, near misses, jumps, and takedowns. Cars will crash if they hit a road car or a piece of the environment, and for a short period of time after a crash the player is able to enter an aftertouch window and attempt to hit another player car with limited movement.

Environments

The game features 7 unique locations inspired by national parks in North America. These locations provide the game's combined 31 courses with over 270 miles of road.

  • Twin Ferry Lakes
  • Dead Rock Canyon
  • Surfside Island
  • Eagle Ridge Mountain
  • High Dunes Desert
  • Grasslands Proving Ground
  • Cool Water Valley

Game Modes

At launch the single player mode will have 69 (nice) events made up from the 9 different event types. New cars are unlocked by progressing through the single player.

Race

The standard event type in Dangerous Driving. A race against 5 computer controller vehicles with Takedowns and Aftertouch active.

Heatwave

A more pure race mode where Takedowns are not active, and completely using the boost bar will trigger a "Heatwave"; an automatic refill of the boost bar allowing for chaining of boosts. Think of this as the Burnout 1/2 mode.

Face Off

A one on one event with a rival vehicle. Take them down, win the race, and win their car!

Shakedown

A pure time trial mode with players racing against the clock to get the best time possible. These events will also serve as a preview for cars yet unlocked.

Eliminator

A five lap race in which last place is eliminated every lap.

GP

A three race series in which points are earned and the champion is determined at the end. There is a GP series for every Class of vehicle.

Survival

A combination of time trial and checkpoint racing. The longer a player goes the tighter the window for the next checkpoint will be and traffic will become heavier.

Pursuit

Play as a cop and takedown the bad guys before they escape!

Road Rage

Get as many Takedowns as possible before time runs out.

Vehicles

Dangerous Driving technically has 27 vehicles across six different classes. That being said, it appears as though there are really only six unique car models, corresponding to the classes, that are then tuned and modified for every variant.

Classes

  • Sedan
  • SUV
  • Coupe
  • Supercar
  • Hypercar
  • Formula DD

Variants

  • Base - The one you start each class of events with.
  • Advanced - Stronger versions that made for Takedowns and Road Rage.
  • Tuned - Faster cars tuned for Heatwave events that earn boost faster, and gain 2 MPH to their top speed after every Heatwave.
  • Prototype - Optimized for racing, these vehicles are tuned to be faster but more fragile.
  • Cop Cars - Sedan, SUV, and Supercar cop cars for all of your pursuit needs.

A train management and simulator game that focuses on running through history as trains became the backbone of society for the expanding United States during the 1800s.

Overview

Zombie Army 4: Dead War is an action-adventure shooter developed and published by Rebellion for PC, Xbox One, and PlayStation 4.

In May 2020 the game was released on the Google Stadia.

System Requirements

PC

PC MinimumPC Recommended
  • Operating System: Windows 10 64-bit / Windows 7 64-bit*
  • CPU: Intel Core i3-6100 (or AMD equivalent)
  • Memory: 4 GB RAM
  • GPU: Nvidia GT 1030 2GB (or AMD equivalent)
  • Storage: 50 GB
  • Other: Windows 7 64-bit version 7601 supported only via the Vulkan launcher option.

column12: Hentai is a platformer game released in September 24, 2017 on Steam. It was developed by PinkySwear. Despite the title, the game is safe for work, as the Hentai refers to the character's name.

Overview

Spare Parts is a co-op action platformer developed by EA Bright Light and published by Electronic Arts Games. Players take on the roles of either Mar-T or Chip, two robots who have been stranded on an alien planet by the dreaded Krofax race. Early in their adventure, Mar-T and Chip come across an abandoned spaceship which houses Con-Rad, the ship's computer (voiced by Simon Pegg). Con-Rad essentially acts as the player's guide, leading them to ship parts that will rebuild the ship to a functional state, allowing them to leave the harsh planet and their dangerous inhabitants.

Gameplay

The gameplay in Spare Parts is centered around players cooperatively exploring the alien world while using upgradeable abilities, such as power arms and rocket boots, to overcome obstacles and find their way to safety. As with many co-op games, Spare Parts can be played either locally on the same console or online. There are "co-op only" abilities and interactions that are only available to two players, giving an strong incentive to experience the game with another player. However, the game can still be played single-player, but unlike most co-op oriented games, it will not feature an AI companion. If players do choose to play cooperatively, they can receive bonuses for simultaneously combining and using certain weapons.

In addition to Mar-T and Chip, other robots have crash-landed or been abandoned on the planet. The players can choose to rescue and repair these robots and unlock them as playable characters.

Server Shutdown

On April 13th 2012, only 15 months after the game was released, the online servers for the game were shut down. No online co-op play was possible after this, although owners of the game can still play co-op locally.

column2: The Infinite Trial of a Hopeless Man Running
column12:
Gameplay

The gameplay consist of dodging numerous obstacles while running towards the finish line. You are running in a straight line with only three set lanes to choose from, the right, left, and center. While you run you can either jump or roll under the obstetrical it. Occasionally other obstacles appear in front of you such as rolling rock or cacti in the path you are running on. There are coins in your path that can be collected and then used as currency in the in-game store, The in-game store is filled with power-ups that aid you in completing your run through of the obstacles, cosmetic "upgrades" for The Gunstringer such as new character models of The Gunstringer and you can even purchase individual accessories such as new boots, new hats, ect. New weapons may also be purchased. The gold collected in game may be used but the game embraces the "Free to play" model which allows you to pay your way up if you choose to do so.

It includes 2 game modes "Story Mode" and "Endless Run" which are similar but endless run allows you to endless run without the liner story elements of the "Story Mode"

The game has Xbox LIVE intigration which allow you to send challenges to 1 or multiple people on you friends list. Leaderboard integration is also present.

The game itself is pretty much a Temple Run clone with a Gunstringer skin over it.
